subject: Law
title: Conspiracy: Agreeing to Commit a Crime
description: A micro-lesson that makes Conspiracy: Agreeing to Commit a Crime usable.

hook.text: Two people agree to rob a store. One buys a mask. Neither enters the store. Both can be charged with conspiracy.

buildup.text: Conspiracy requires an agreement between two or more people to commit a crime, plus an overt act in furtherance.

discovery.text: The crime is the agreement itself. The underlying crime doesn't need to actually happen.

twist.text: Prosecutors love conspiracy charges because they allow charging all participants for each other's actions.

climax.text: Pinkerton liability means one conspirator can be convicted for crimes committed by another in the conspiracy.

punchline.text: In conspiracy, agreeing is the crime. Doing it is extra.

quiz.question: What is required for a conspiracy charge?
options: An agreement plus an overt act
